document.docAuthor: Paresque, Karla, Martín, Guillermo San, Álvarez-Campos, Patricia, Nogueira, João Miguel De Matos & Fukuda, Marcelo Veronesi
document.docTitle: Paraopisthosyllis kuluguhin Paresque, Martín, Álvarez-Campos, Nogueira & Fukuda, 2016, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Two new species and new records of the genus Paraopisthosyllis Hartmann-Schröder, 1991 (Annelida: Syllidae) from northeastern Brazil and Philippine Islands

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Two new species and new records of the genus Paraopisthosyllis Hartmann-Schröder, 1991 (Annelida: Syllidae) from northeastern Brazil and Philippine Islands

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 1. Geographic distribution of species of
Paraopisthosyllis
and ocean surface temperature gradient around the world. World temperature data was obtained from BioOracle (Tyberghein et al . 2012).

subSubSection.paragraph: Description. Incomplete specimen. Body anteriorly broad, slender from midbody ( Fig. 2 A–B), 5.5 mm long, 0.5 mm wide, with 43 chaetigers; posterior segments used for molecular analysis. Dark, pigmented area dorsally on each segment, irregularly distributed on anterior segments, with conspicuous pattern after proventricle, as one anterior pigmented short band and two lateral areas ( Fig. 2 B); lateral pigmented areas disappearing on posterior segments; dark areas on cirrophores of large dorsal cirri ( Fig. 2 A, C). Small, scattered papillae on lateral and ventral surfaces, more numerous on dorsum ( Fig. 2 A–C); some papillae longer, others with capitate tip ( Fig. 2 A– E). Prostomium oval, four small eyes arranged in open trapezoidal pattern, almost in straight line; antennae missing ( Fig. 2 A). Palps broad, longer than prostomium, folded ventrally ( Fig. 2 A). Peristomium shorter than subsequent segments; peristomial cirri elongated ( Fig. 2 A). Dorsal cirri of two sizes, larger ones distally inflated, club-shaped, provided with dark inclusions, inserted latero-dorsally ( Fig. 2 A, C), others distinctly smaller, located laterally ( Fig. 2 A); most larger dorsal cirri missing, probably those of chaetigers 1–4 inflated, subsequent dorsal cirri alternating inflated and not inflated, without dark inclusions; from midbody, difference in sizes not so marked ( Fig. 2 B). Dorsal cirri with distinct cirrophores. Compound chaetae with light spinulation on shafts of dorsal-most and intermediate chaetae on anterior and midbody chaetigers, remaining shafts smooth; blades short, distinctly bidentate, slightly spinulated on anterior body and on dorsal-most chaetae from midbody, remaining falcigers with smooth blades ( Fig. 3 A, C, E). Each anterior parapodium with two dorsalmost compound chaetae with slender shafts and blades, blades 20 µm long, remaining six chaetae per fascicle with wider shafts and blades ( Fig. 3 A), blades 19–15 µm long; midbody and posterior parapodia with eight compound chaetae each, blades and shafts slightly progressively larger and wider posteriorwards, blades 15 µm long dorsally, 9 µm long ventrally ( Fig. 3 C, E). Dorsal simple chaetae on posterior chaetigers, slender, unidentate, slightly spinulated, with thin spines distally ( Fig. 3 D). Ventral simple chaetae not seen. Anterior parapodia with three distally irregularly rounded to truncate aciculae each ( Fig. 3 B), single acicula on each posterior parapodium, as anterior ones. Pharynx wide, through 3–4 segments; pharyngeal tooth not seen. Proventricle, longer than pharynx, extending through 3–4 segments, with 35 muscle cell rows ( Fig. 2 A).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 2.
Paraopisthosyllis kuluguhin
sp. nov.
(A) holotype, anterior body, dorsolateral view; (B) midbody segments, dorsal view; (C) dorsal cirrus; (D) large papilla from dorsal surface; (E) small papilla from dorsal surface. Scale bars: A, B = 0.18 mm; C = 48 µm; D, E = 20 µm.

FIGURE 3.
Paraopisthosyllis kuluguhin
sp. nov.
(A) falcigers, anterior parapodia; (B) aciculae, anterior parapodia; (C) falcigers, midbody parapodia; (D) dorsal simple chaeta, posterior parapodia; (E) falcigers, posterior parapodia. Scale bar: 20 µm.
TABLE 1. Morphological comparison between the known species of Paraopisthosyllis .

tr.th: Length/Width (mm) 6.7/0.5 Number of chaetigers 59 Secondary annulation on segments Absent
1-2 dark areas/segment. Absent Dorsal cirri with dark spots
Brown dorsal bands on anterior Red spots segments. Prostomium, palps and dorsal cirri brown
Irregular dark area dorsally on anterior chaetigers; after proventricle, each chaetiger with one anterior and two lateral short and pigmented bands
Unidentate; bidentate on Unidentate anterior parapodia

subSubSection.paragraph:
Secondary annulation on segments Absent Present Absent Present Absent Fusion of segments Absent Absent Absent Absent Present Remarks.
Paraopisthosyllis kuluguhin
sp. nov.
resembles
P. brevicirra
and
P. alternocirra
(see Table 1 and San Martín & Hutchings 2006 ), in alternating short and long dorsal cirri on anterior body, distinct dark inclusions in the median antenna and in the large dorsal cirri, and a similar color pattern. However, it differs from
P. alternocirra
, in having distinctly bidentate compound chaetae.
Paraopisthosyllis phyllocirra
also has bidentate compound chaetae, but the blades have longer spines on margin, and the inflated dorsal cirri end by an acute tip ( Hartmann-Schröder 1991 ; San Martín & Hutchings 2006 ;
Aguado et al. 2015b
). In addition, the presence of papillae of at least two different sizes, the longest ones distally capitate, is a unique characteristic within the genus.

tr.th: Dark transverse areas on Red-brown antennae and dorsal cirri; Red-brownish spots median antenna and dorsal several transverse dark red-brown cirri lines per segment
Large transverse red stripe per segment; on Transverse dark band per anterior chaetigers additionally a rhomb on segment some segments

tr.td: Fusiform, thicker ones Club-shaped Leaf-shaped with a distal button

tr.th: Position of pharyngeal tooth Posterior half

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. The specific name comes from the Tagalog (Austronesian language spoken in the Philippines ), meaning “ verrucose ”.
